tossups.question: In “Explanation and Understanding,” one thinker argues that scientific explanation implicitly uses a methodology from this field. One text written by the so-called “father” of the modern version of this field speaks of a divinatory method in this field. A “circle” named after this philosophical field refers to how one’s understanding comes from each different part, in reference to the (*) whole. Paul Ricoeur developed a suspicious version of this field. Another thinker in this field said that this field should be a universal principle and should work in a mother tongue and foreign language; that thinker was Friedrich Schleiermacher. A priority towards prejudgement was argued by Gadamer in his approach to this discipline, which is seen in his Truth and Method. For 10 points, identify this philosophical subdiscipline about textual interpretation.
tossups.answer: hermeneutics [prompt on interpreting texts or similar before mention] <HB>

tossups.question: Works by this artist are displayed over the opening credits of Bernardo Bertolucci’s film Last Tango in Paris. In the biographical film Love is the Devil, Daniel Craig played a burglar who became this artist’s lover. While destroying an art gallery in Tim Burton’s Batman, the Joker spares a famous painting by this artist because he “kind of [likes] it”. This artist created numerous depictions of a wounded (*) nurse from The Battleship Potemkin. This artist is the favourite painter of David Lynch, whose mutant baby in Eraserhead resembles the rightmost figure in this artist’s triptych Three Studies for Figures at the Base of a Crucifixion. For 10 points, name this Irish-born painter who was inspired by a Velazquez portrait to paint screaming popes.

This politician called music critic Paul Hume an “eight ulcer man on four ulcer pay” and threatened to beat the crap out of him after Hume published a negative review of a concert by his daughter. This president fired Attorney General J. Howard McGrath after McGrath fired a special prosecutor investigating corruption in the Internal Revenue Bureau for being too zealous. This president’s former business partner, Eddie Jacobson, influenced his decision to recognize the state of (*) Israel. This president criticized the “Do-Nothing” Congress, and he is depicted in a photograph holding up an incorrect headline by the Chicago Tribune, which claimed that Thomas Dewey had defeated him. For 10 points, name this president who authorized dropping the atomic bomb on Japan.

Edmund Gosse’s review of this novel asks “What has providence done to [the author] . . . that he should shake his fist as his creator?” The postscript to this novel says that it was burned by a bishop before being discovered as a “moral work.” A character in this novel once walked into a pond with bare legs, shouting ‘Move on, aunty! This is no sight for modest eyes!” When called a “flirt,” that character responds that she is “a woman tossed about, all alone, with aberrant passions” and states “I am not really Mrs. Richard (*) Phillotson.” In this novel, the title character’s love interest refuses to have sex with him until she becomes jealous of a woman who had his baby in Australia, Arabella Donn. For 10 points, name this novel about a working-class boy who falls in love with Sue Bridehead while trying to get into university, the final novel by Thomas Hardy.

A paper by Tsvi Piran on sources of this radiation conjectures that the “inner engine” driving that source is the formation of a compact object. The strongest consistent source of radiation in this band is the Crab Nebula. Starquakes in magnetars are thought to be the cause of emissions of this radiation called (*) SGRs. A satellite equipped with very fast momentum wheels to observe short, highly directional emissions of radiation in this band is named Swift. One of NASA’s Great Observatories named for Compton observed this band of radiation. The “relativistic fireball” model explains one source of this radiation. Extremely energetic events are called “bursts” of this radiation. For 10 points, name this type of radiation of shorter wavelength than X-rays.

In one revolt against this colonial power, slaves snuck cane knives into a fort in bundles of wood, overpowered a fort’s garrison, then established an African-style kingdom for six months. Accra’s Osu Castle was built by this colonial power and formerly named for one of its monarchs. This country colonized the Indian ports of Serampore and Tranquebar, and sold its Caribbean territories (*) to the US in 1917. Those territories were the present-day US Virgin Islands. Admiral Ove Gjedde led this country’s East India Company, and it established the West African forts of Frederiksborg and Christiansborg. This country today retains sovereignty over its former colonies of the Faeroe Islands and Greenland. For 10 points, name this Northern European country with its capital at Copenhagen.

A character created by this man complains that, “with absolutely no humor,” a different character gives a “heartbreaking and earsplitting rendition of Carrie Jacobs Bond’s ‘End of a Perfect Day.’” This playwright reworked his earlier Battle of Angels into a different play, a subplot of which follows Dolly and Beulah. This playwright created a character who believes he is made of “Indian rubber,” but who drops dead at the age of 97 after finishing his last poem. In a play by this author of Orpheus Descending, a tour guide uses the phrase “swimming to (*) china” as a euphemism for suicide. This man wrote a play that ends when T. Lawrence Shannon liberates the title reptile. This playwright of The Night of the Iguana also created Jim O’Connor, a “gentleman caller” who visits Amanda Wingfield. For 10 points, name this American playwright of The Glass Menagerie.

One chronicle of people with this title has an illuminated Madrid edition that contains key images of early weaponry. One epic poem about a person with this title is the first known work of written Swahili. Yet another person with this title had a wife who was accused of performing a nude dance called “Leda and the Swan” and was himself described as having killed a (*) trillion people by a historian who didn’t like him all that much. Another person with this title was chronicled in a history written by his daughter; that man’s invitation of Frankish forces into his domain is described in the Alexiad, a history dating from the Commenos Dynasty. For 10 points, name this title, one of whose holders was slammed in Procopius’ Secret History, held by rulers of an empire headquartered at Constantinople.

Unusually, the opacity of this material is constant across wavelengths and is identically equal to pi times the fine structure constant, and does not depend on any material parameters. In these materials, the energy bands meet at the six corners of the first Brillouin zone. A half-integer quantum Hall effect and non-zero geometric phase for electrons are observed in this material. Confusingly, the classical (*) effective mass for electrons in these materials diverges, while electrons actually behave “massless” in these materials, which combined with ballistic transport leads to the extremely high conductivity of this material. This material was first created through the use of scotch tape. For 10 points, name this material, a single layer thick hexagonal grid of carbon atoms.

In a ritual related to this god’s wife, a young girl is chosen to walk through a village wearing only flowers while older women pour water on her. This god’s wife, the Sun, may have been shared with the god of the underworld while the sun was down at night. The Byzantine historian Procopius was the first to note the triumphs of this god whose image was often carved into the largest oak tree in a village among his worshippers. A god who usually appeared as a (*) bear but could shapeshift was defeated by this god after stealing this god’s cattle and family. That god, Veles, was chased back to the base of the world tree by this god. This god rides a chariot pulled by a goat buck, has either an axe or a hammer and is the son of Lada and Svarog. For 10 points, name this chief Slavic god of thunder and lightning.

The Algerian nationalist hero Abd el-Kader attempted to quell a 1860 outbreak of sectarian violence that originated from this modern-day country, which resulted in the deaths of 10,000 in the capital of a neighboring country. A saint, though not born in this country, was notable for spreading Christianity to this modern-day country and converted people such as Abraham of Cyrrhus (*), who is sometimes known as the Apostle of this country. A 1943 National Pact in this country agreed upon by its different ethno-religious groups says the prime minister of this country must be a Sunni Muslim. A smaller religious group in this nation is currently led by Walid Jumblatt. This country, along with Syria and Israel, contains the majority of the world’s Druze. For 10 points, name this Middle Eastern country, whose city of Bkerké is the headquarters of its Maronite church.

In one novel by an author with this surname, a character keeps and rereads a patronizing letter from her former friend letting her take care of her autistic brother in a house he owns. That author with this surname created a vegetarian exchange student who discovers that Melanie, the daughter of his barbecue-loving host family, is bulimic. In that novel, Uma becomes a spinster despite her parents’ efforts to arrange her marriage. Another author with this surname wrote about an Anglophile judge being forced to prepare tea for a group of (*) Nepalese rebels who recruit his granddaughter’s teacher Gyan. Fasting and Feasting is by an author with this surname, as is a novel where Biju tries to make a living in America while the orphan Sai grows up in India. The Inheritance of Loss is by an author with, for 10 points, what surname shared by Anita and her daughter Kiran?
tossups.answer: Desai [or Anita Desai; or Kiran Desai] <DS>

tossups.question: Pseudomonas infections in cystic fibrosis can enhance their biofilms through incorporation of this protein and DNA from dead neutrophils. In Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome, blood cells lack the required complexes of this protein. CDC42 activates the WAS protein as part of a pathway to build this protein. A “comet tail” structure is formed as pathogens hijack the the host’s supply of this protein to move around, such as in (*) Listeria. The Arp2/3 complex allows this protein to branch out at a 70 degree angle, such as at the lamellipodia, or leading edge, of motile cells. The beta variant of this protein is a common loading control for gel electrophoresis. Calcium binding to troponin allows this protein to open up its binding sites for myosin, leading to muscle contraction. For 10 points, name this structural protein found in microfilaments.

The first violins introduce a work by this composer that goes F, A-flat, B-flat, C, in a short, long, short long, rhythm before a chromatic descent in the second violins and violas. The second theme of a work by this composer begins with a half note A-flat, then eighth notes B-flat, A-flat, D-flat, E-flat, F and is marked moderato cantabile. Ernst Oster said in a 1947 paper, said this composer composer didn’t want to publish a particular piece during his lifetime due to the resemblance to (*) Beethoven’s Moonlight Sonata. This composer wrote a work that opens with the left hand playing octave G-sharps which prominently features a four versus three cross rhythm. This composer’s etudes includes ones nicknamed Aeolian Harp, Black Keys, and Revolutionary. For 10 points, name this composer of Fantasie Impromptu and the Minute Waltz.

Bioleaching of iron and copper with Thiobacillus results in the production of metal ions and this substance. In electrowinning of copper, the electrodes are placed in a solution of this substance. Reaction of this substance with sodium or potassium chloride is used to produce hydrogen chloride in the Mannheim process. This substance is added to phosphate containing rocks in the (*) “wet method” of phosphoric acid production. The lead chamber process for producing this substance was superseded by a process using a vanadium oxide catalyst, called the contact process. This substance is the electrolyte in lead-acid batteries. Oil of vitriol is, for 10 points, an old name of what strong acid, the most produced industrial chemical, with formula H2SO4?

The lyric “back to Kokomo” was replaced with “back to Chicago” in a song by this artist which may actually refer to Port Chicago, California. This musician, who was said to be influenced by Skip James, is the subject of a 2004 tribute album by Eric Clapton called Me and [This Musician]. In one song by this artist, he said “I'm goin' to call up in China, just to see if my baby's over there;” that song is “Dust My Broom.” This artist opens another song with “I went to the (*) crossroad, fell down on my knees.” This musician was among the first inductees into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame for his early influence from albums like King of the Delta Blue Singers. For 10 points, name this blues singer-songwriter from Mississippi, who supposedly sold his soul to the devil to be a great guitarist.
tossups.answer: Robert Johnson [accept Mr. Johnson because the album is called Me and Mr. Johnson] <HB>

tossups.question: John and Beatrice Whiting studied this process in six cultures including the Tarong in the Philippines and the Gusii of Kenya. In her book about identical twins, No Two Alike, Judith Rich Harris argued that a system named after this process, along with systems named after relationships and status, affects personality. Leo Vygotsky claimed that consciousness or awareness resulted from this process. Preparation for bias and a promotion of mistrust are typical of the (*) racial version of this process while the primary version of this process occurs through caregivers. Norms are learned through this process that also can help mold a human’s personality. For 10 points, name this process in which individuals acquire elements of culture.
tossups.answer: socialization [accept enculturation before the end, prompt after; accept stuff like learning the elements of culture or becoming an adjusted member of society; prompt on learning social norms] <HB>

tossups.question: During this war, a city nicknamed “City of Blood” by its inhabitants was recaptured by Operation Jerusalem. That recapture presaged a large-scale invasion of one of its combatants called Operation Dawn. One side during this war gave its child soldiers plastic keys before sending them into minefields and was attacked by the United States during Operation Praying Mantis. Israel also intervened in this war to destroy a nuclear (*) reactor at Osirak. Praying Mantis was part of the “tanker war” that took place in the waterways surrounding this war’s theater of operations. The city of Khorramshahr in the region of Khuzestan was the site of heavy bombardment during this war, which was caused by a border dispute on the Shatt al-Arab waterway. For 10 points, name this war fought from 1980 to 1988 between two oil-rich middle Eastern countries.

According to a poem by Robert Pinsky, poems about these events ask the questions “What is someone?” and “What is a nobody?” Armand d’Angour is best known for a pair of poems about these events. An advocate for these events promoted them with the 1833 poem “Dialogue of the Dead.” Another poem about these events begins “Water is best, and gold, like a blazing fire in the night, stands out supreme of all lordly wealth.” That poem tells the story of Pelops, whose fame “shines from afar” at these events. The ghost of Plato asks where these events have gone in the first (*) modern poem about these events, a work by Panagiotis Soutsos. In 1912, an award in poetry was given at one of these events to Pierre de Coubertin. For 10 points, name these events celebrated by Pindar’s victory odes, at which Greeks competed athletically.
tossups.answer: Olympic games [or Olympics, prompt on games or athletic events or similar; accept Isthmian or Pythian games before “Armand” is read]

tossups.question: After a recent election, this party had to reach a compromise on coal power to join a coalition with 3 smaller parties. The current leader of this party had popularized the 2010 Un-word of the year. One person in this non-Canadian party helped his countrymen set up financial accounts in Alberta, which was linked to the Airbus affair. That former member of this party was extradited from Canada in 2009. This party was the subject of a 1999 (*) financial scandal in which Karlheinz Schreiber donated one million DM to this party illegally. This party is a part of the European People’s Party and it may enter a “Jamaica coalition.” For 10 points, name this center right political party of Angela Merkel, that is opposed by the Social Democrats in Germany.
tossups.answer: Christian Democratic Party of Germany [prompt on CDU, accept Christlich Demokratische Union Deutschlands, accept CDU-CSU but do not accept CSU by itself because it’s a different party] <HB>

tossups.question: (TB) A group during this war was organized by Lauchlin Currie and Thomas Corcoran. During this war, the siege of Myitkyina was undertaken during the monsoon season, which took a toll on the jungle-commando unit nicknamed Merrill’s Marauders. The formation of a group during this war was debated and approved at the Trident Conference. An advisor during this war advocated for the transfer of supplies via the Ledo Road, instead of flying the supplies over “the Hump.” Joseph (*) Stilwell advised Chiang Kai-shek during this war. A group of American pilots during this war had shark mouths painted onto their fighters, and were nicknamed the “Fighting Tigers.” For 10 points, name this war, during which the United States interned Japanese-Americans at internment camps.
tossups.answer: World War II [or the Second World War; prompt on World War] <JO> Bonuses:

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, answer the following related to the parables of Jesus.
answers: Parable of the Prodigal Son [or Lost Son]
parts: A beggar with this name goes to heaven while a rich man goes to hell in one parable. Another Biblical person with this name was the brother of Mary of Bethany and Martha.
Known as the 31st parable in Luke 15, this parable tells of a son who, after being given a fortune, squanders it and runs away from home only later to be welcomed back by his father.

In the third parable from Matthew, Jesus says that people do not put this object underneath a bowl but instead put it on a stand. In the sixth parable, this object on a stand is again mentioned and Jesus says "For there is nothing hidden that will not be disclosed."

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about old people named MacDonald, some of whom presumably owned farms, in Scottish history. For 10 points each,
parts: A lot of MacDonalds were killed at this 1692 attack by English forces on sleeping Highlanders, instigated by the head of Clan MacDonald’s inability to go to London to swear a loyalty oath.

After one of these events, which took place in both 1715 and 1745, Flora MacDonald helped the pretender Bonnie Prince Charlie escape Scotland to France. They were named for the Latin form of “James”, and consisted of the Stuarts attempting to retake the English throne.

The MacDonalds largely took the English Civil War as an excuse to fight this centuries-old rival clan of theirs. This clan held the Earldom of Argyll and made up a significant portion of the Covenanters’ support.

bonuses.leadin: The Einstein-Smoluchowski relation is a formula for the coefficient which characterizes this process. For 10 points each:
answers: fluctuation-dissipation theorem [do NOT accept or prompt on “fluctuation theorem”]
parts: Name this process where entities move from regions of high concentration to regions of low concentration.

The Einstein-Smoluchowski relation is an example of a consequence of this theorem, which relates a microscopic and macroscopic process. The expressions for Johnson-Nyquist noise also follow from this theorem.

Brownian motion is an example of a Wiener process, which is the continuous limit of this kind of stochastic process. In one or two dimensions one of these processes almost surely returns to the origin, while in three dimensions and higher this is not the case.

bonuses.leadin: The main character of this novel gives his father Jakob a book about birds for his birthday despite that character never reading anything except the Bible. For 10 points,
answers: aunt (the other book mentioned is Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter)<DS>
parts: Name this novel about policeman Pieter, who is married to Nella but gets caught violating the Immorality Act for sleeping with a black woman named Stephanie.
Too Late the Phalarope is by this South African author best known for writing about Stephen Kumalo in Cry, The Beloved Country.

Too Late the Phalarope is narrated by a character with this relation to the protagonist. Julia Urquidi wrote a memoir called What Little Vargas Didn’t Say in response to an autobiographical novel titled after her in which Mario courts a person said to have this relationship to him.

bonuses.leadin: The lost city of Iram of the Pillars, mentioned in the Quran, may have been irrigated by this structure. For 10 points each,
answers: Ma’rib Dam [accept Great Dam of Ma’rib; prompt on Great Dam]
United Arab Emirates [prompt on Abu Dhabi] <JM>
parts: Name this earthen structure on the Wadi Adanah, a massive feat of 18th-century-BCE engineering that included a canal and a tank to store its excess water.
This country’s Himyarite Kingdom depended on the Ma’rib Dam for much of its water supply. The Ma’rib dam collapsed after an invasion from the Axum kingdom conquered this country.

The Ma’rib Dam was rebuilt after a lapse of 14 centuries by a sheikh of Yemeni descent from this country in 1986. This country’s wealthy cities of Abu Dhabi and Dubai ensured that he had the money to do so.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about infomercials and the people who sell things on them. For 10 points each,
parts: This legendary longtime pitchman for OxiClean, Fix-it, and Zorbeez was succeeded by Anthony Sullivan after his 2009 death.
This super-absorbent rag, which a Consumer Reports test found was objectively superior to Zorbeez, was invented and pitched by Vince Shlomi.

This inventor of GLH and pitchman of the Veg-o-matic was the subject of an essay in Malcolm Gladwell’s What the Dog Saw. After being disowned by his inventor father, he began distributing his inventions through his own company, Ronco.

bonuses.leadin: You put on a VR headset, taking you inside the nucleus of a human cell letting you walk along DNA sequences. For 10 points each:
answers: MHC [or HLA, or major histocompatibility complex, or human leukocyte antigen]
parts: The ends of chromosomes consist of these repetitive units which decrease in number each time DNA is replicated. The shortening of these regions make cells reach their hayflick limit.

When visiting chromosome 6, you notice that regions the short arm don’t have a consensus sequence. That’s because parts of it codes for this highly variable cell surface protein complex that distinguishes self from nonself.
Upset at the fact that only about 1% of the human genome is coding, you decide to head to this most gene-dense chromosome. This chromosome also has the largest human cluster of KRAB-ZFP genes.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about interruptions of the Spanish monarchy. For 10 points each,
answers: Amadeo I [accept Amadeus, prompt on Amadeo] <JM>
parts: Isabella II was overthrown in an event of this name. In another event of this name, the Immortal Seven invited a Dutch invasion of their country.
This fascist dictator ruled for 39 years without a monarch after defeating the Republicans in the Spanish Civil War.
This Spanish king of the Savoy Dynasty who took power after the Glorious Revolution was himself deposed following the Hidalgo Affair. After this, the Bourbon Dynasty was restored.

bonuses.leadin: Contemporary creators of these works include Paa Joe and Eric Anang. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these works which developed from the tradition of “figurative palanquins.” Unusual creations of this type by the Kane Kwei Carpentry Workshop have emulated a lego brick, a frozen dinner, and a garbage truck.
Fantasy coffins are an art form from this African country. British architect David Adjaye is a citizen of this country.

Fantasy coffins first become known outside Ghana in a 1989 exhibition at the Pompidou Centre, which was designed by this architect. This Italian architect also designed Kansai International Airport and “The Shard.”

bonuses.leadin: The speaker of this poem notes that Nature “speaks a various language” to anyone who can hold “communion with her visible forms.” For 10 points each:
answers: “A Fable for Critics” (by James Russell Lowell) <JO>
parts: Name this poem, a “meditation on death” that was written by an editor of the New York Evening Post.
“Thanatopsis” and “To a Waterfowl” are poems by this 19th-century American poet.

Bryant is called as “dignified as a smooth, silent iceberg” who is in “supreme ice-olation” in this satirical poem, which describes another author as “three fifths of him genius and two fifths sheer fudge.”

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the career of Jesse James. For 10 points each:
parts: During the Civil War, James fought as a “bushwacker” in this state. This Midwestern state was governed by Lilburn Boggs, who issued the “Extermination Order” against Mormons.

James’ mother Zerelda was forced to leave Missouri by General Order Number 11 after Quantrill raided this state’s town of Lawrence. It experienced so much violence before the Civil War that it was considered to be “Bleeding.”

The downfall of the James-Younger gang began after their failed attempt to rob the First National Bank in this Minnesota town. A reason for targeting the bank was due to a rumored deposit by former General Adelbert Ames.

bonuses.leadin: These entities form above their namesake critical concentration. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these entities with hydrophilic “heads” facing the solvent, while the hydrophobic “tails” remain on the inside.

At the critical micelle concentration, several parameters abruptly cease changing as additional surfactant molecules preferentially form micelles, especially this quantity, since it is more favourable for surfactant molecules to be completely within the solvent.
Micelles can only form above this temperature, since the solubility of the surfactant is too low below this temperature. It is named for a German chemist.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about the geography of Australian aborigines. For 10 points each,
answers: Uluru [prompt on Ayers Rock if someone answered the bonus before it was fully read]
Gibson, Great Victoria, or Great Sandy Deserts <JM>
parts: This large sandstone formation is a sacred place for many Aboriginal groups. Before a name change, it was known as Ayers Rock.

This region of Australia’s Northern Territory bordering the Gulf of Carpentaria is home to a huge number of aboriginal groups living a largely traditional lifestyle. The territorial capital of Darwin is located in this region.
The three main deserts of Western Australia all have majority-aboriginal populations. Name any of the three.

bonuses.leadin: The concert aria “Ah se in ciel” was written for this singer, who also had the part of Madame Herz in the premiere of Der Schauspieldirektor. For 10 points each:
answers: Aloysia Weber [or Aloysia Lange, prompt on “Weber”]
parts: Name this singer, who starred as Donna Anna in the 1788 Vienna Premiere of Don Giovanni. Another aria written for her, “Popoli di Tessaglia,” reaches a high A6.

Aloysia Weber starred in the 1785 revival of The Abduction from the Seraglio in this lead female role. The plot of that opera revolves around this character’s lover Belmonte trying to rescue her from harem of Pasha Selim. Curiously, this character has a similar name to the wife of the composer of that opera.
Aloysia’s sister Josepha starred as the Queen of the Night in the premiere of this Mozart opera, which is titled after the enchanted instrument the Queen of the Night gives to Tamino and Papageno.

bonuses.leadin: Connections under this protocol begin with a three-way handshake, and this protocol retransmits dropped packets unlike an alternative protocol. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this transport layer protocol, paired with IP when referring to the whole Internet protocol suite, which provides reliable data transfer.

Bytes 16 and 17 of a TCP header are used for one of these values used for basic error correction. Hashes generated from by MD5 or SHA1 are frequently used as these values for files downloaded over potentially insecure channels.

When establishing a TCP connection, the client sends a SYN segment to the server, to which the server responds with another SYN segment to synchronize the sequence number, as well as this segment to confirm that the request was received.

bonuses.leadin: In 1997, Spanish novelist Javier Marias was bequeathed the monarchy of an uninhabited Caribbean island called Redonda. For 10 points each, name some of his dukes and duchesses.
parts: This author was named Duke of the Island of the Day Before, in reference to his novel of that title. He also wrote Foucault’s Pendulum.
This Canadian author was named Duchess of Ontario. Her Juliet stories are included in Runaway, and her most recent collections are Too Much Happiness and Dear Life.
This director was named Duke of Tremula, in reference to the original title of his film Live Flesh. His most recent film is a Spanish-language adaptation of Munro’s Juliet stories called Julieta.

bonuses.leadin: This situation occurs when a person is correctly morally evaluated despite the fact that much of what the person is assessed on is beyond their control. For 10 points each:
parts: Identify this situation, that Bernard Williams said he first thought was an oxymoron.
This thinker identified four types of moral luck in his 1979 essay on the subject. This NYU professor also wrote about consciousness in “What Is it Like to Be a Bat?"
This principle about moral luck says, according to Nagel, “people cannot be morally assessed for what is not their fault.”

bonuses.leadin: This thinker worked undercover as a Playboy bunny in the 1960s as part of an article for Show magazine. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this feminist thinker, who advocated personal development in Revolution from Within: A Book of Self-Esteem who famously said “a woman needs a man like a fish needs a bicycle.”

Steinem was one of the founders of this feminist magazine along with Dorothy Pitman Hughes. The first cover of this magazine contained a picture of Wonder Woman and a 2006 article in this magazine was called “We Had Abortions.”

Another feminist author, Judith Butler, was often compared to Steinem regarding their seemingly conflicting views on male to female transsexuals. Butler is most famous for a book titled for this concept’s Trouble. It is often compared to sex.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about how to end a piece of music, for 10 points each:
parts: The final two chords of a melody from one of these progressions, usually a perfect one if it ends the melody. These progressions in the middle of a melody are usually denoted as “half” ones.
The first chord in a perfect cadence in minor will usually have an accidental on this scale degree. This scale degree number forms a tritone with the 4th scale degree.

If a song in four part harmony ends with the sequence 3-2-1 in the melody, and the first of those notes is harmonized using a cadential six-four chord, what is most likely sequence, using scale degrees, of the bass line?

bonuses.leadin: At the end of this story, the narrator sees his hat floating in the water and uses its motion to guide his ship out of the shallows. For 10 points,
parts: Name this homoerotic short story about a captain who finds a naked man in the water and conceals him in his bunk.

“The Secret Sharer” was written by this author, who also wrote about another sailor in the South Pacific for his autobiographical story “Youth.” He spent twenty years in the merchant marine after leaving his native Poland.
While serving as first mate of the Torrens, Conrad met this traveller, who helped inspire his literary attempts. This Nobel winner is best known for his 15-book series, The Forsyte Saga.
